articles.headline: Stocks Worldwide Fall and Oil Spikes on Unrest in Libya
articles.snippet: The unrest in Libya dominated European and Asian markets with investors wondering which oil-producing country might be next to face turmoil.
articles.abstract: The unrest in Libya dominated European and Asian markets with investors wondering which oil-producing country might be next to face turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rising political turmoil in Libya sent jitters through global financial markets, with European shares falling on Monday and Asian markets starting out sharply lower on Tuesday.

articles.headline: American Held in Pakistan Worked With C.I.A.
articles.snippet: Raymond A. Davis, an American arrested after shooting two men at a traffic stop, worked with a covert team tracking Pakistani militant groups, officials said.
articles.abstract: Raymond A. Davis, an American arrested after shooting two men at a traffic stop, worked with a covert team tracking Pakistani militant groups, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was written by Mark Mazzetti, Ashley Parker, Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Ashley Parker, Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: For Pepsi, a Business Decision With Social Benefit
articles.snippet: PepsiCo’s work with corn farmers in Jalisco, Mexico, reflects a new approach by corporations trying to maintain a business edge while helping out small communities.
articles.abstract: PepsiCo’s work with corn farmers in Jalisco, Mexico, reflects a new approach by corporations trying to maintain a business edge while helping out small communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN GABRIEL, Mexico  In the past, farmers would make the dangerous trek north from this tiny town hidden in the rugged folds of the Jalisco mountain range to the United States, hoping to earn enough money doing odd jobs to cover debts incurred while cultivating the small plots of land that have been in their families for generations.

articles.headline: Union Bonds in Wisconsin Begin to Fray
articles.snippet: Wisconsin, once a pioneer in supporting organized labor, has become a battleground over unionized public workers and their role in the budget woes.
articles.abstract: Wisconsin, once a pioneer in supporting organized labor, has become a battleground over unionized public workers and their role in the budget woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Rich Hahn worked at the General Motors plant here until it closed about two years ago. He moved to Detroit to take another G.M. job while his wife and children stayed here, but then the automaker cut more jobs. So Mr. Hahn, 50, found himself back in Janesville, collecting unemployment for a time, and watching as the city’s industrial base seemed to crumble away.
articles.byline: By A. G. Sulzberger and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Child-Product Makers Seek to Soften New Rules
articles.snippet: Trade groups representing makers of toys and other child products are trying to quash new safety regulations.
articles.abstract: Trade groups representing makers of toys and other child products are trying to quash new safety regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emboldened by a Republican majority in the House of Representatives, manufacturers of toys and other children’s products are making a last-ditch effort to quash new safety regulations that they say are unfair or too onerous.

articles.headline: Japanese Stock Market Is Getting New Respect
articles.snippet: Its economy may be a mess, but investors say Japan may become the best-performing market.
articles.abstract: Its economy may be a mess, but investors say Japan may become the best-performing market.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s government finances are on the verge of collapse, and its economy has floundered for two decades.

articles.headline: Midlevel Taliban Admit to a Rift With Top Leaders
articles.snippet: Defeats and weariness are creating fissures between the top leadership based in Pakistan and midlevel field commanders, who have borne the brunt of fighting.
articles.abstract: Defeats and weariness are creating fissures between the top leadership based in Pakistan and midlevel field commanders, who have borne the brunt of fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Recent defeats and general weariness after nine years of war are creating fissures between the Taliban’s top leadership based in Pakistan and midlevel field commanders, who have borne the brunt of the fighting and are reluctant to return to some battle zones, Taliban members said in interviews.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Grip on the Capital Tightens as Revolt Grows
articles.snippet: Vowing to kill protesters “house by house,” Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tightened his grip on Tripoli, but the eastern half of the country was slipping beyond his control.
articles.abstract: Vowing to kill protesters “house by house,” Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tightened his grip on Tripoli, but the eastern half of the country was slipping beyond his control.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOBRUK, Libya  Vowing to track down and kill protesters “house by house,” Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tightened his grip on the capital, Tripoli, on Tuesday, but the eastern half of the country was slipping beyond his control.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Pirates Brutally End Yachting Dream
articles.snippet: Jean and Scott Adam shared a dream through 15 years of marriage: to retire, build a boat and sail the world. The dream came to a brutal end on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Jean and Scott Adam shared a dream through 15 years of marriage: to retire, build a boat and sail the world. The dream came to a brutal end on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jean and Scott Adam shared a dream through 15 years of marriage: to retire, build a boat and sail the world. And that is precisely what they did, heading out in 2004 from Marina Del Rey, Calif., on a custom-built 58-foot yacht for a permanent vacation that brought them to exotic islands and remote coastlines: Fiji, Micronesia, China, Phuket.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Home Prices Slid in December in Most U.S. Cities, Index Shows
articles.snippet: The Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller price index fell to nearly its lowest level since the housing crash began.
articles.abstract: The Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller price index fell to nearly its lowest level since the housing crash began.
articles.lead_paragraph: Real estate prices slid in just about every part of the country in December, pushing a housing market that once seemed to be rebounding nearly back to its lowest level since the crash began.
